But the Globe, Clinton, Obama, BLM, and all other left wing political critics of Trump steadfastly never talk about it.
column9: While there is a germ of truth here, the framing that black men shoot each other more than cops shoot black men is devoid of context and meant to amplify the already sterotypical representation of black men as a source of violence.

column2: Over 800 black males have been shot or killed by other black males in CHicago this year so far.   On a national level, black males are about 3000% more dangerous to each other than are cops. But the Globe, Clinton, Obama, BLM, and all other left wing political critics of Trump steadfastly never talk about it.
column9: On the surface the comment reads as "factual" by quoting statistics, but there are a few concerns: 1) The author makes these claims without citing any source for where they got the information, so it's impossible to know if it's true or not without doing one's own research. 2) Whether true or not, the unverified statistics reinforce a harmful stereotype about black men and violence. There is not enough context about the broader conversation where this comment was posted, but one has to wonder whether selectively quoting statistics that reinforce a stereotype is appropriate rhetoric (e.g. how does this 3000% number compare to the danger men pose to one another without race as a factor?) and thus comes across as more inflammatory. 3) Using the phrase "black males" instead of "black men" is dehumanizing as it describes members of a subgroup of a racial identity group in scientific versus humanistic terms. Because of the stereotype it's identity-based negativity and insulting, and additionally it's threatening because such language has been historically used to encourage violence against Black men. There is no profanity present. The stereotyping makes this very toxic and on its own would make me likely to leave the discussion, with the author's clear implications about the motives of certain individuals and organizations only increasing that likelihood.

Also, I would say that this is toxic but not "very toxic" because it is insulting and uses questionable argumentative tactics that can be considered unreasonable, but is not extremely aggressive or hateful. To say a bit more about why the author's argument is toxic, I will nitpick on definitions; "car[ing] less what race a person ascribes to be" does not actually mean that one is not racist; it refers to the phenomenon of "colorblindness" which some argue is actually a racist position, so the author's deflection of what was presumably a prior accusation comes across as overly defensive without actually giving a helpful reason. For this reason I might want to leave this conversation depending on how much energy I have to engage with someone who does not seem interested in any self reflection.

column9: I said yes for insult because the commenter calls the left "the bastion of hatred and intolerance," a clear insult. I also said yes for identity-based negativity because of the way the speaker refers to certain groups of people. Langauge like "the blacks" and "the gays" is often considered offensive because of the way it "others" people from marginalized groups compared to the more humanizing language "Black people" and "gay people". Because of the insult and questionable identity related language, I called this toxic, but not very toxic, since insults directed at other ideological parties, while not nice or poltie, are quite common in political discussions and not extreme enough for very toxic.. Additionally, the underlying point the author was trying to make, while lost in the exagerated language being used, was not in itself a harmful argument. I said that I would leave the discussion because assertions such as "All the ____ who voted for Trump are ____", implied to be said by the opposing party, and the resulting conclusion that "the left is the basion of hatred and intolerance", are classic examples of a straw man fallacy--distorting the other side's opinions into such extreme statements and then countering those rather than the actual statement. Such an absolute argument leaves no room for debate on the topic, making a healthy discussion impossible.

column9: There are a few insults here, though most are not directly towards people. "Twisted and lopsided interpretation" and "drivel" are directed at ideas rather than people, though there is an implication that the author has negative views about the person being quoted. Similarly, the misspelling of "Fox News" as "FAUX Ooze" is insulting, but towards a TV network, which is a bit ambiguous as well because a TV network is not a person. There is also an insult in the quote directed towards Hillary Clinton, but this is a quote and not the author's sentiment, so again that does not qualify as an insult. However, I did mark this comment as an insult because of the last instance: the author additionally misspells "Rush Limbaugh" as "Lush Rimbaugh", which is directly mocking a specific person. This, along with the author's general mocking tone, make this toxic, but I would not classify it as very toxic because the mocking is a somewhat rude form of political satire rather than hateful. I'm not sure if I would leave the conversation because I feel similarly to the author, however if this person continued to use inflammatory language I would leave the conversation. There is no profanity, threatening language, or identity-based negativity expressed here.
